byline.original: By KAREEM FAHIM, ANTHONY SHADID and RICK GLADSTONE
byline.contributor: Kareem Fahim reported from Misurata and Tripoli, Libya; Anthony Shadid from Beirut, Lebanon; and Rick Gladstone from New York. Reporting was contributed by Denise Grady and J. David Goodman from New York; and Eric Schmitt, Mark Mazzetti and Robert F. Worth from Washington.

abstract: Libyan leader Col Muammar el-Qaddafi is killed as fighters battling the vestiges of his fallen regime finally take control of his hometown of Surt; official version of events offered by Libya's new leaders, that Qaddafi was killed in crossfire, do not appear to be supported by photographs and videos streamed over the Internet, in which Qaddafi's bloodied body is shown with bullet holes apparently fired into his head at close range, in possible execution by anti-Qaddafi fighters.
snippet: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi was killed Thursday as fighters battling the vestiges of his fallen regime took control of his hometown of Surt after a prolonged struggle, the interim government said.

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )

lead_paragraph: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi was killed Thursday as fighters battling the vestiges of his fallen regime took control of his hometown of Surt after a prolonged struggle, the interim government said.

headline.main: Violent End to an Era as Qaddafi Dies in Libya
headline.sub: Conflicting Reports of Killing Reflect Libya’s Instability
headline.seo: Qaddafi Dies in Libya, Marking an Era’s Violent End
headline.print_headline: Qaddafi, Seized by Foes, Meets a Violent End
